entry.title: Re: How to handle “usernames”, “Global User IDs” and “external IDs” in your landscape?
entry.content:
Hi @1Gunnar @Colt 

I'm curently using the UUID based on the Entra Atribute as per https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity/system-integration-guide/step-by-step-example-for-setting-up-global-user-id

but unfortunately this can be done only to non-employees since the employees are syched from SSFF to IAS and the UUID is autogenerated and written back to SF as part of the standard integration and this currently is not switchable.

I'm using the Subject name Identifier with the Global User ID for al applications that allow it. Even in case of Joule or taskcenter currently it's mandatory to use that way and also the UUID has to be provisioned to SU01. This requieres a change in the principal propagation and the Cloud Connector does not accept different configs, so in the end you have to use UUID for everything. In case of SAC for example, you can setup using SAML SSO using "Custom Attribute" and use the UUID as Subject name identifier that should match the custom SAML atribute defined in the SAC user.

entry.title: The Future of Procurement: ESG, Sustainability, and the Circular Economy
entry.content:
In the rapidly evolving world of corporate procurement, sustainability and ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) have moved from buzzwords to business imperatives. Recent conversations with industry leaders, as captured in SAP’s “The Future of Procurement” podcast, reveal how organizations are navigating this complex landscape—balancing regulatory demands, stakeholder expectations, and the pursuit of competitive advantage.

We had a conversation with Japen Holist, Head of Sustainability Go-to-Market in North America at SAP, on the latest ESG and Sustainability Trends in Corporate Procurement. Japen helps define what ESG means for corporations and draws on his own experiences to explain why procurement plays such a large role in corporate sustainability efforts.

Is sustainability just about regulatory compliance? Why does technology play such a large role in corporate ESG initiatives, and how can improving ESG measures lead to competitive advantages? 

ESG: Beyond Compliance to Strategic Value

ESG is no longer just about regulatory compliance; it’s a framework for evaluating intangible drivers of company value, from brand reputation to future growth potential. The shift from shareholder to stakeholder capitalism—championed by the World Economic Forum—means companies must consider the impact of their actions on employees, suppliers, communities, and the environment. While some argue that ESG initiatives can cut into profits, forward-thinking leaders see them as opportunities to differentiate, build trust, and unlock new markets.

Sustainability Trends in Procurement

Procurement organizations are at the forefront of driving sustainability. Key trends include:

  • Sustainable Sourcing: Companies are prioritizing responsible sourcing, green buying, and supplier diversity. Real-world examples, like Patagonia’s repair program, show how sustainable practices can foster customer loyalty and brand advocacy.
  • Regulatory Compliance: With increasing regulations, especially in regions like Europe and California, organizations must adapt quickly or risk falling behind. Most companies respond reactively, but proactive compliance can be a market differentiator.
  • Social Impact: Labor rights, fair treatment, and community engagement are gaining prominence. Initiatives like the Uyghur Force Labor Protection Act highlight the need for collaboration—even among competitors—to solve systemic supply chain challenges.
  • Governance: Transparency and accountability are now critical. Ethical behavior, supplier audits, and risk assessments are becoming standard practice, moving procurement from adversarial negotiations to collaborative partnerships.

The Circular Economy: Mimicking Nature for Competitive Advantage

Perhaps the most transformative trend is the rise of the circular economy. Instead of the traditional linear model—extract, produce, dispose—companies are reimagining processes to eliminate waste and reuse resources. The story of Interface Carpet, which redesigned its products and processes to mimic nature, demonstrates how circularity can drive down costs, reduce environmental impact, and create lasting competitive advantages.

Data, Technology, and the Road Ahead

Sustainability is increasingly a data problem. Accurate measurement of carbon emissions, water usage, and other metrics is essential for managing risks and meeting regulatory requirements. Technology platforms, especially ERP systems, are enabling organizations to automate data collection and analysis, paving the way for AI-driven decision-making. As reporting standards become stricter and supply chains more complex, those who embrace transparency and collaboration will thrive.

Conclusion: Embracing Change for a Sustainable Future

The future of procurement is bright but challenging. Success will require a mindset shift—viewing sustainability not as a cost, but as a catalyst for innovation and growth. By harnessing data, fostering collaboration, and embracing circularity, organizations can turn ESG from a regulatory hurdle into a strategic asset. As the landscape continues to evolve, now is the time for procurement leaders to reflect, adapt, and lead the way toward a more sustainable and resilient future.

Let’s connect!
How is your organization approaching ESG and sustainability in procurement? Share your experiences, challenges, or success stories in the comments—or reach out directly to continue the conversation.

🌐OpenSAP:

https://podcast.opensap.info/future-of-procurement/2025/04/29/episode-016-exploring-esg-sustainability-trends-in-procurement-with-japen-holist-part-1/

https://podcast.opensap.info/future-of-procurement/2025/05/06/episode-017-exploring-esg-sustainability-trends-in-procurement-with-japen-holist-part-2/

🍎Apple Podcasts:  Parts 1 & 2

https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-future-of-procurement/id1764078646?i=1000705402905

https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-future-of-procurement/id1764078646?i=1000706498083

🎵Spotify: Parts 1 & 2

https://open.spotify.com/episode/7Dxy7pFpTY8xZuY7t4xis3?si=DzyDYYvsQ3CFZQSfshfaXA

https://open.spotify.com/episode/4oR1YXLcbVM4anVxz4MYyY?si=CGvFdo85RHiPy27pTbWrUw

#Procurement #Sustainability #ESG #CircularEconomy #SupplyChain #BusinessTransformation #SAP #Leadership #Innovation #SpendManagement

entry.title: From Foundation to Future: Master Data Management as the Fuel for Gen AI
entry.content:
In today's fast-paced business landscape, the role of Master Data Management (MDM) has evolved significantly, transitioning from a fundamental process improvement tool to a critical enabler of advanced analytics and AI. Join us for an interactive webinar, "From Foundation to Future: Master Data Management as the Fuel for Gen AI," where we delve into the evolution of MDM and its pivotal role in empowering next-generation AI technologies.

What to Expect

Introduction to The Hackett Group and Their Latest MDM Study

Kickstarting our session, we will introduce The Hackett Group and share insights from their latest 2025 MDM study. This will set the tone for our detailed discussion on the evolution and impact of Master Data Management.

Traditional Applications of MDM

We will then explore the traditional applications of MDM, highlighting its role in business process improvement. Through line-of-business-specific examples, you'll gain a clear understanding of how MDM has been utilized to streamline operations and enhance efficiency.

Contemporary MDM Use Cases

Diving deeper, we will examine more contemporary MDM use cases to illustrate how clean master data drives effective analytics, AI, and ultimately, improved decision-making. These examples will underscore the transformative potential of MDM in today's data-driven world.

SAP Master Data Governance

We will weave in throughout the capabilities of SAP Master Data Governance, demonstrating its role in achieving operational excellence and accurate analytics. Moreover, we will discuss how AI within MDM is driving new value and accelerating business process excellence.

Meet Our Speakers

Bryan DeGraw, Market Intelligence Analyst

Bryan DeGraw, Market Intelligence Analyst at The Hackett Group, is the author of their MDM Matrix Study. His insights and expertise in MDM will provide a comprehensive understanding of its past, present, and future.

Andreas Seifried, SAP MDM Product Management

Andreas Seifried, from SAP MDM Product Management, will share his knowledge on how SAP Master Data Governance can fuel enable businesses to stay ahead in the competitive marketplace.

Why Attend?

1. Insightful Perspectives: Gain valuable insights from industry experts on the evolution of MDM.
2. Practical Examples: Learn from real-world examples that demonstrate the impact of MDM on business processes and decision-making.
3. Future Trends: Understand how MDM is shaping the future of AI and how you can leverage it for your organization.
4. Interactive Session: Engage with our speakers through Q&A sessions and interactive discussions.

Register Now!

Don't miss out on this opportunity to explore how Master Data Management is impacting the business landscape. Register now to stay ahead of the curve and discover how MDM can be the fuel your organization needs to harness the power of Gen AI and secure operational excellence.

We look forward to seeing you at the webinar!

entry.title: Re: Automatic PO with Goods Receipt
entry.content: To get details about (and options for) submitting your questions to SAP Community, please see the Asking and Answering Questions in the Community Af... - SAP Community. You may also want to watch How do I ask a question from a category page? as this how-to video illustrates one approach for posting a question to SAP Community. Before you ask a question, please browse the community in case this question has been answered already. If you need to create a new question, start with a descriptive title that briefly outlines what your question is about. A clear question title will help community members gain a quick initial understanding of your question. It will also help community members find your question (and its answers) when they are searching for solutions to similar problems. When writing your question, please share what steps you took that led you to your question. If you don't, community members might tell you to take actions you've already tried yourself. Make sure that your question is very specific. Provide as many details as you can -- such as which product version you are using and what error message you're receiving. Include screenshots if possible.

entry.title: Re: How to handle “usernames”, “Global User IDs” and “external IDs” in your landscape?
entry.content:
Hello,

the Cloud Connector allows rules to create the string in the username-certificate. The default is something like "CN={name}" and often contains the email. To not break BTP integrations with older features or stacks I would now add a condition like "IF userUuid is present in the token" create a different string like "CN={name}, OU={userUuid}".

With this approach the S/4HANA in scope for newer integrations like SAP Task Center or SAP Joule could be configured in the CERTRULE to look for the "OU={userUuid}" in the certificate and identify the user with Global User ID.

The other stacks e.g. older versions using the same Cloud Connector could still consume the CN from the certificates.

For very new S/4HANA stacks even an OIDC integration with Cloud Identity is now possible, but it depends on the requirements if this a feasible architecture for your landscape. 

In general, please use the Cloud Identity Services in front of your SAP landscape. New features rely on this and even activities outside of SAP could break alternative integration flows e.g. iFrames.

BR
Gunnar

entry.title: Re: How to handle “usernames”, “Global User IDs” and “external IDs” in your landscape?
entry.content:
Hi @1Gunnar 

I thought of such rule but the problem is that "user_uuid" is as per default included in the attributes when configuring a new subaccount. So all the subaccounts are currently having user_uuid  in IAS app and passing it to BTP. Techincally I'm not using it for all global accounts except for the Joule/TaskCenter ones where the UUID is also the SNI. For the rest of the subaccounts we're currently using Login Name to match SU01 user ID and we'd like to keep it that way for now until we can do a full switch to UUID for everithing.

Disabling the user_uuid attribute in IAS for the Subaccounts not using Global user ID should not technically cause any problem then?

entry.title: TDS Limit in SAP Based on total invoice amount for fiscal year done.
entry.content:
Hi Team,

I got a requirment from business which is i got find to done with customization with the help of enhancement,

Purpose / Objective:

The purpose of this Business requirment implementing a TDS (Tax Deducted at Source) threshold limit configuration in SAP.
Currently, the system deducts TDS on every invoice amount without checking the cumulative transaction value for each vendor at PAN.

This leads to incorrect or non-compliant deductions.

The objective of this development is to ensure that TDS is deducted only after the total transaction value for a PAN exceeds the statutory threshold limit (₹50,00,000) within a financial year.

Business Requirement

TDS should be deducted only when the cumulative invoice/payment value for a vendor PAN in a financial year exceeds ₹50,00,000.
The system must check the total amount posted for each vendor PAN from the start of the fiscal year (April) and apply TDS only when the threshold is crossed.

 

Functional Requirements:

 

TABLE

Description

INPUT Logic.

FIELD

OUTPUT                               

LFA1

Fetch Vendor by Vendor PAN detail.

Vendor PAN

J_1IPANNO

Vendor Code of same PAN

LFBW

Pass Vendor Code and get the vendor with withholding tax type 194Q-4Q

Vendor Code which I got from LFA1(J_1IPANNO)

WITHT

Vendor Details which only have TDS type 194Q-4Q

As a Functional i have created the logic but i am confuged with from which table i can pick vendor invoice amount( which is final net amount after all kind of case which can reduce vendor invoice line item except vendor payment) I triend with BSEG, But BSEG is very big table, It will not work with BSEG. Please help me with the other solution other than BSEG, I avoid BSEG here, If only BSEG help here please give a clear logic. But provide any other solution.

entry.title: Re: Material Purchase Text Not Printed for Subcontracting...
entry.content:
In your case, why it is happening is because, Subcontracting items (category L) are treated differently in SAP Public Cloud. The system prioritizes component-level texts because the BOM explosion logic assumes that the supplier needs details about the components being sent for processing. The main material's purchase text is not automatically retrieved or printed in the PO output for these items.

You explored BAdI MMPUR_PO_STD_ITEM_TEXT, which is technically the right enhancement spot. However, in the subcontracting context, input variables are often empty or not populated early enough, making it ineffective for injecting the main material’s purchase text.

Explore the below some workaround options

If you're using SAP Forms by Adobe, consider enhancing the form logic to explicitly fetch the purchase text for the main material using the material number from the PO item. This can be done via CDS view extension and Custom logic in the form data provider class (if available in your edition)

Create a custom text field or use an unused standard text type to manually maintain the main material’s purchase text. Use output parameter determination to include this text in the PO output.

While MMPUR_PO_STD_ITEM_TEXT is limited, you might explore CDS views like I_PurchaseOrderItemText or I_MaterialText to fetch the required text. Use Custom Logic (via In-App Extensibility) to enrich the PO item data before output generation.

entry.title: Forecasting in Intercompany Stock Transfer Scenario
entry.content:
Hi All,

Issue Statement: Forecasting in Intercompany Stock Transfer Scenario

We are working with an intercompany stock transfer setup in SAP S/4HANA, where:

  • Plant A is the supplying plant under Company Code A
  • Plant B is the selling plant under Company Code B

The challenge arises in the forecasting process:

  • The sales demand originates from Plant B, making it the logical source of truth for forecasting.
  • However, consumption postings (e.g., movement types 687 and 601) are recorded against Plant A, the supplying plant.

This creates a disconnect between where the demand is generated (Plant B) and where consumption is posted (Plant A), which complicates the forecasting process. How can I get the forecast consumption ? 

 

  • How should forecasting be handled in this scenario to ensure accurate demand planning at Plant B?
  • Is there a standard SAP approach to link consumption data from Plant A back to Plant B for forecasting purposes?
  • Should we consider custom logic or reporting to reflect true demand at Plant B?

entry.title: Re: TDS Limit in SAP Based on total invoice amount for fi...
entry.content:
Here are the tables and strategies you can use to avoid BSEG while still getting accurate invoice totals:

Use Table BKPF + BSIK/BSIS (Open Items) or BSAK/BSAS (Cleared Items). BKPF for Document header table. Use it to filter by fiscal year, company code, document type, and posting date. BSIK for Vendor open items (subset of BSEG). BSAK for Vendor cleared items (subset of BSEG). These tables are much smaller and indexed for performance.

Logic is as follows:

  • Join BKPF and BSIK/BSAK using BELNR, BUKRS, and GJAHR and filter by:
  • LIFNR (Vendor Code)
  • BUDAT (Posting Date) between April 1 and March 31
  • SHKZG = 'H' (Credit entries)
  • WRBTR (Amount in document currency)

If your TDS is applied on MM invoices, this is a cleaner route: Check RBKP for MM invoice header and RSEG MM invoice line items.

Logic is as follows:

  • Filter by LIFNR, BUDAT, and fiscal year.
  • Use WRBTR from RSEG for net amount.
  • Join with RBKP to get posting date and vendor.

If you're using New GL, use table FAGLFLEXA which is a powerful alternative and filter by Filter by LIFNR / BUDAT / WRBTR / RACCT. This table is optimized for reporting and supports cumulative logic well.

Finally, if none of the above options work and BSEG is the only source then, from performance tip point of view, use index tables like BSIK, BSAK, or clustered selects with FOR ALL ENTRIES. Always filter by fiscal year, company code, and vendor. Avoid SELECT * — only pull required fields like WRBTR, BELNR, BUKRS, GJAHR, LIFNR.

So with the above, the logic summary would be

  • Get PAN → Vendor Codes using LFA1 and J_1IPANNO
  • Filter Vendors with WHT Type 194Q-4Q using LFBW
  • Fetch Invoice Amounts using:
  • Preferred: BSIK, BSAK, RBKP, RSEG, FAGLFLEXA
  • Fallback: BSEG with optimized filters
  • Aggregate by PAN and Fiscal Year
  • Apply TDS only if cumulative > ₹50,00,000

entry.title: Re: Regular Vendor: Single Material - Mutiple Purchase or...
entry.content:
The root cause of your issue is Regular Vendor assignment in SAP is material-centric, not Purchase Organization-specific. This means when you assign a regular vendor for a material, SAP updates the record globally for that material, not scoped to a specific Purchase Org. Even though Purchase Organizations 1000 and 2000 belong to different company codes, SAP still treats the regular vendor as a single field in the material master (typically in the purchasing view), not differentiated by org. The warning message “Up to now, supplier XYZ has been the regular supplier for this material” confirms that SAP is referencing a global setting.

So the recommended approach would be to use Info Records Instead of Material Master. Maintain vendor-specific info records for each Purchase Organization and material combination. In the info record, you can define the regular vendor per Purchase Org, which is more granular and avoids overwriting.

If your business process requires regular vendor assignment per Purchase Org in the material master, consider a custom enhancement. Explore user exit or BAdI (e.g., ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST) to control or validate vendor assignment. Store the regular vendor per Purchase Org in a custom Z-table and reference it during procurement processes.

Could you please let me know who can provide the required certificate? Should I request it from the client?

 

Thanks

Durga

entry.title: Re: Stock provided to vendor
entry.content:
Some workaround options are available to fix your issue

If the parts are physically at the vendor but GR was posted to your plant, do Transfer Posting with Movement Type 541 to transfer the stock to the subcontracting vendor. This will move the stock from your plant to the vendor’s special stock (O stock type). This ensures the stock is no longer considered available at your plant and is correctly reflected at the vendor.

If the GR was posted incorrectly and you want to correct it, reverse the GR using Movement Type 102. Then repost the GR to the correct location or vendor using the appropriate movement type (e.g., 101 to correct plant or 541 to vendor). This is the cleanest method if the error is recent and hasn't triggered downstream processes.

So with the above, the impact on MD04 would be

  • it will no longer show the stock as available at your plant.
  • MRP will recalculate based on the corrected stock situation.
  • You may need to run MD02 or MD03 to re-trigger planning for the material.

entry.title: ABAP code to wait for the end of "inbound bgRFC type Q" units
entry.content:
I have a program which runs parallel tasks in the same system via qRFC by using bgRFC. This scenario is called Inbound bgRFC type Q. Each task is called a unit. For more information about bgRFC, see here: bgRFC (Background Remote Function Call) | SAP Help Portal.

After the units are all started, I want to wait for them.

I propose a simple ABAP method which should work for most of situations.

There are really very few posts about bgRFC and the official documentation is missing information too, so I hope it can help some people. Note: I don't even know if the classes I use are supported by SAP and if it's the right way to do it, so all comments are welcome, thank you.

Here is the context how this method is used (WAIT_END_OF_QRFC_INBOUND_UNITS):

DATA(inbound_destination) = cl_bgrfc_destination_inbound=>create( 'ZZZ' ).

LOOP AT any_table INTO line.
  DATA(unit) = inbound_destination->create_qrfc_unit( ).
  unit->add_queue_name_inbound( line-queue_name ).

  CALL FUNCTION '...' 
     IN BACKGROUND UNIT unit
     EXPORTING ...

  INSERT unit INTO TABLE units.
ENDLOOP.

COMMIT WORK.

DATA(wait_results) = wait_end_of_qrfc_inbound_units(
                       i_watch_delay_seconds = '0.5'
                       i_units               = units ).

Little explanation: there's an internal table containing data which needs to be processed in parallel via a given RFC-enabled function module. The internal table assigns given queue names to each line of data in order to achieve the parallelization. For instance, one half of the table goes to the queue named Z1,  all calls in Z1 will be executed sequentially,  the other half goes to the queue named Z2, the calls in Z1 and Z2 will be executed in parallel).

COMMIT WORK creates the inbound bgRFC units in the database (function module calls and parameters) and all the queues are started by the bgRFC scheduler. You can see the units via the transaction SBGRFCMON.

Prerequisite: the inbound destination ZZZ was created via the transaction SBGRFCCONF. Nothing else needed (no prefix, no RFC destination in SM59, queue names are assigned freely by the program, etc.)

Here's the code of the method WAIT_END_OF_QRFC_INBOUND_UNITS:

CLASS zcl_bgrfc_helper DEFINITION FINAL CREATE PRIVATE.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    TYPES ty_qrfc_inbound_units TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF REF TO if_qrfc_unit_inbound WITH EMPTY KEY.
    TYPES:
      BEGIN OF ty_bgrfc_unit_state,
        unit         TYPE REF TO if_qrfc_unit_inbound,
        "! Time at which the information was collected
        timestamp    TYPE timestampl,
        unit_success TYPE abap_bool,
        unit_error   TYPE abap_bool,
        "! In case there's a unit error
        unit_state   TYPE bgrfc_unit_state,
        queue_error  TYPE abap_bool,
        "! In case there's a queue error
        queue_state  TYPE qrfc_queue_state,
      END OF ty_bgrfc_unit_state.
    TYPES ty_bgrfc_unit_states TYPE SORTED TABLE OF ty_bgrfc_unit_state WITH UNIQUE KEY unit.

    CLASS-METHODS wait_end_of_qrfc_inbound_units
      IMPORTING i_watch_delay_seconds      TYPE numeric DEFAULT 5
                i_units                    TYPE ty_qrfc_inbound_units
      RETURNING VALUE(r_bgrfc_unit_states) TYPE ty_bgrfc_unit_states.

    CLASS-METHODS get_timestamp
      RETURNING VALUE(r_result) TYPE timestampl.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS zcl_bgrfc_helper IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD wait_end_of_qrfc_inbound_units.
    TYPES:
      BEGIN OF ty_queue,
        queue_name TYPE qrfc_queue_name,
        dest_name  TYPE bgrfc_dest_name_inbound,
      END OF ty_queue.
    TYPES tt_queue TYPE SORTED TABLE OF ty_queue WITH UNIQUE KEY queue_name dest_name.
    TYPES:
      BEGIN OF ty_unit_and_queue,
        unit       TYPE REF TO if_qrfc_unit_inbound,
        queue_name TYPE qrfc_queue_name,
        dest_name  TYPE bgrfc_dest_name_inbound,
      END OF ty_unit_and_queue.
    TYPES tt_unit_and_queue TYPE SORTED TABLE OF ty_unit_and_queue WITH UNIQUE KEY unit
                            WITH NON-UNIQUE SORTED KEY by_inbound_queue COMPONENTS queue_name dest_name.

    DATA ls_unit_and_queue TYPE REF TO ty_unit_and_queue.

    DATA(lt_queue) = REDUCE #(
                    INIT lt_queue_2 = VALUE tt_queue( )
                    FOR <lv_unit> IN i_units
                    FOR <lv_queue_name> IN <lv_unit>->get_queue_names_inbound( )
                    NEXT lt_queue_2 = COND #(
                         WHEN NOT line_exists( lt_queue_2[ queue_name = <lv_queue_name>
                                                           dest_name  = <lv_unit>->destination->dest_name ] )
                         THEN VALUE #( BASE lt_queue_2
                                       ( queue_name = <lv_queue_name>
                                         dest_name  = <lv_unit>->destination->dest_name )  )
                         ELSE lt_queue_2 ) ).

    DATA(lt_unit_and_queue) = VALUE tt_unit_and_queue( FOR <lv_unit> IN i_units
                                                       FOR <lv_queue_name> IN <lv_unit>->get_queue_names_inbound( )
                                                       ( unit       = <lv_unit>
                                                         queue_name = <lv_queue_name>
                                                         dest_name  = <lv_unit>->destination->dest_name ) ).
    WHILE lt_unit_and_queue IS NOT INITIAL.

      WAIT UP TO i_watch_delay_seconds SECONDS.

      LOOP AT lt_unit_and_queue REFERENCE INTO ls_unit_and_queue.
        DATA(bgrfc_unit_state) = cl_qrfc_client_inbound=>get_unit_state( ls_unit_and_queue->unit->unit_id ) ##NEEDED.
        CASE bgrfc_unit_state.
          WHEN if_bgrfc_client=>unit_state_runnable
            OR if_bgrfc_client=>unit_state_in_execution
            OR if_bgrfc_client=>unit_state_blocked ##NO_HANDLER.
          WHEN if_bgrfc_client=>unit_state_executed.
            r_bgrfc_unit_states = VALUE #( BASE r_bgrfc_unit_states
                                           ( unit         = ls_unit_and_queue->unit
                                             timestamp    = get_timestamp( )
                                             unit_state   = bgrfc_unit_state
                                             unit_success = abap_true ) ).
            DELETE lt_unit_and_queue USING KEY loop_key.
          WHEN OTHERS.
            r_bgrfc_unit_states = VALUE #( BASE r_bgrfc_unit_states
                                           ( unit       = ls_unit_and_queue->unit
                                             timestamp  = get_timestamp( )
                                             unit_state = bgrfc_unit_state
                                             unit_error = abap_true ) ).
            DELETE lt_unit_and_queue USING KEY loop_key.
        ENDCASE.
      ENDLOOP.

      LOOP AT lt_queue REFERENCE INTO DATA(queue).
        DATA(bgrfc_queue_state) = cl_qrfc_client_inbound=>get_queue_state( queue_name = queue->queue_name
                                                                           dest_name  = queue->dest_name ).
        CASE bgrfc_queue_state.
          WHEN if_bgrfc_client=>queue_state_runnable
            OR if_bgrfc_client=>queue_state_in_execution
            OR if_bgrfc_client=>queue_state_empty ##NO_HANDLER.
          WHEN OTHERS.
            LOOP AT lt_unit_and_queue REFERENCE INTO ls_unit_and_queue
                 USING KEY by_inbound_queue
                 WHERE     queue_name = queue->queue_name
                       AND dest_name  = queue->dest_name.
              r_bgrfc_unit_states = VALUE #( BASE r_bgrfc_unit_states
                                             ( unit        = ls_unit_and_queue->unit
                                               timestamp   = get_timestamp( )
                                               queue_state = bgrfc_queue_state
                                               queue_error = bgrfc_queue_state ) ).
              DELETE lt_unit_and_queue WHERE unit = ls_unit_and_queue->unit.
            ENDLOOP.
            DELETE lt_queue USING KEY loop_key.
        ENDCASE.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDWHILE.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD get_timestamp.
    GET TIME STAMP FIELD r_result.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

As I said, I don't know if these classes are released by SAP:

  • cl_qrfc_client_inbound=>get_unit_state
  • cl_qrfc_client_inbound=>get_queue_state 

The method should support units which span other several inbound queues, but I didn't test it.

In my case, I could see that one unit has these states: runnable (briefly), in execution, executed. In a given queue, there's only one unit processed at a time. All the units instantiated after the one processed have the state blocked. Other states should be errors (e.g. short dump, uncaught exception, error message, etc.)

The queues have these states: empty if it doesn't contain any unit, runnable if it contains at least one unit to execute but it's not started yet, in execution when a unit is processed.

About the code, in case you want to ask: "DELETE itab USING KEY loop_key" is to delete the current line in the loop (LOOP AT itab), it corresponds to the old and less expressive syntax "DELETE itab". I used the pragma ##NO_HANDLER for CASE WHEN although it's not asked by the syntax check, the pragma is meant to be used for CATCH, when there's no code inside. 

Any way, feel free to post any comment.

Thank you for reading.

entry.title: Re: Forecasting in Intercompany Stock Transfer Scenario
entry.content:
Please understand the disconnect in your process

  • Sales demand originates at Plant B, which is responsible for customer-facing activities and should drive the forecast.
  • Consumption postings (e.g., movement types 687, 601) are recorded at Plant A, the supplying plant, due to the nature of intercompany stock transfers.
  • This leads to forecasting inaccuracies, as standard consumption-based forecasting tools in SAP S/4HANA Cloud rely on historical consumption data—available only at Plant A.

So the recommended forecasting strategy would be to consider Plant B as the Forecasting Anchor. Forecasts should be generated based on sales orders and historical demand at Plant B, not consumption at Plant A. This aligns with the business reality that Plant B drives customer demand.

Leverage Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer (Scope Item 5HP). SAP’s advanced intercompany process includes document flow tracking and valuation in transit, which can help reconcile demand and consumption across plants2. Use the Monitor Value Chains app to trace the flow from sales order at Plant B to goods issue at Plant A.

Use forecasting tools like Predictive Material and Resource Planning (pMRP) or Demand-Driven Replenishment (DDR) with input from Plant B’s sales history. These tools allow manual overrides or external forecast inputs, which can be derived from your custom logic.

There is no standard SAP automation that links consumption at Plant A directly to demand at Plant B for forecasting. Therefore custom logic is essential to bridge this gap. Consider creating a forecast consumption proxy at Plant B using Historical intercompany STOs, Sales order quantities and Delivery schedules.

entry.title: Why does 's (an apostrophe followed by an s) hinder the duplicate check in ARIBA SLP?
entry.content:
I have a supplier request with the exact match with another supplier that is already in the database (Address and contact information is 100% match - the legacy supplier was imported from SAP, if that makes a difference. ) Yet, the request was not flagged for a duplicate check.

When I try this out - it seems that the complete address and contact information with the name (as an example) ABC BBQ SAUCE is giving me a 89% match. But if I add 's to make it ABC'S BBQ SAUCE there is no duplicate records flagged.

Any ideas on this would really be helpful moving this forward!

SAP Ariba Sourcing SAP Supplier Lifecycle Management

You can still use CJ40 by creating a tile for it from the App Finder in Fiori and searching in the SAP Menu.

entry.title: 2H 2025 Product Release - Question about LRN-152514 - iContent management
entry.content:
After reading through the provided documentation for this release feature, I still had a few questions:

  1. We do not use the "Content Upload" tool within the LMS - we have built our own custom upload tool. Will we still be able to use the iContent Admin functions that are being released?

  2. Within our iContent storage, there are 2 folders - TestContent and Content. From the documentation, it states that deleting iContent files is only available in Production Systems. Does this mean that, from our Production Environment, we'll be able to delete items in the TestContent folder on iContent? If we do that, will the related Items and Content Objects in our lower environment LMS also be deleted? Or would we need to manually identify and delete those?

  3. Each SCORM content item has its own folder. Will the delete process delete the folders, or only the contents within them, leaving vast quantities of empty folders scattered around our iContent space?

entry.title: Alternative GR/IR account for procurement
entry.content:
We have a requirement to have an alternative GR/IR account for certain types of consumption/service procurement postings. For this we assigned a valuation class to a material group in the SSCUI 'Entry Aids for Items Without a Material Master' (101602), created a G/L account and configured this in the SSCUI 'Automatic account determination'. But the system is not picking our alternative GL account for the GR/IR posting key in the goods receipt, instead it is posting to the delivered GR/IR Account.

 

 

 


--- Steps to Reproduce ---

Log in into the dev system, and check the configuration. Create the PO for procurment of material group DIGITS and the account detrmination is not rflecting as expected, the one configured. Instead it is taking the standard G/L.



*Note To SAP:
I give approval for SAP Support to use these Steps to Reproduce, while connected to my impacted non-production environments, even if the steps result in a change being made and my approval remains valid until the issue is resolved, unless I inform SAP Support otherwise.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Alternative GR/IR account for procurement
entry.content:
Refer to the SAP KBA 2828996 - How to determine GL account using Material Group

The assignment of a valuation class to a material group is made in the configuration node 'Entry Aids for Items Without a Material Master' (SSCUI: 101602)
Please note that, using this valuation class, the G/L account is determined in the purchase order if no material master record exists.
The determination of the GR/IR clearing account always takes place with an initial valuation class.

entry.title: Setup communication of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition for e-submission
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to provide a step-by-step guide to help you configure and integrate SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition or SAP S/4HANA Private Edition, specifically for electronic submission of statutory reports.

The communication and integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition is available for a number of supported compliance reports per country / region (in both S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or On-Premise). Through the list(s) above, all already delivered supported compliance tasks which relates to Submitting Statutory Reports Using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition as supported submission types are relevant for communication setup and application configuration. 

This blog post will provide you with a walkthrough to help you navigate through the different configuration aspects within the SAP Help portal.  With simple setup steps and the configuration of your environment you will achieve proper communication of your business system with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition and authentication to the tax authorities. 

The value of the integration between SAP S/4HANA business systems and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition lies in the fact the setup of the various steps shown below need to be done only once for communication purpose – once done the main communication is then available for all reports.

Then, once you have completed specific application configuration for your reporting entity and communication settings specific for your report, a single click submits the report from your business system (through the application Run Statutory Reporting) and triggers the entire flow to electronic submit to the tax authority.

The configuration/set up required for each compliance report is depicted below:

Configuration on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition business system:

  • Scope Item Activation (78L): Before starting, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition must have the communication scenario SAP_COM_0854 available for configuration of the communication in your business system.  If your report is listed on the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition supported compliance tasks with supported submission type as  Submitting Statutory Reports Using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition, please request activation of the scope item 78L (more information in the SAP Note 3387894).
  • Onboarding to the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition: If you have entitlement through your license then the next step is the Initial Setup of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition.
  • Connecting the Cloud Edition and the Business System: After onboarding, you must setup the Integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with your S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition business system.
    • Communication Setup details, with all the information required, are available at:
      • setup instruction of the scope item 78L or 
      • Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP S/4HANA Cloud 
  • Reporting Configuration in the Business System and Cloud Edition: The final step is the specific configuration for your report.  Here you need to complete the following two main configurations: 
    • Configure your process-specific setting and authentication method for your reports per country/region in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition (SAP BTP). Please verify it per your specific report at Process-Specific Setting.
    • Configure each statutory report by following the steps in the individual configuration documentation. This can be found by navigating to the links in the Reports column in the Reports Enabled for Electronic Submission..

Configuration on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition business systems:

  • Implementing Required SAP Notes: Before starting, the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition or On-Premise must contain the required implementation objects.  Each report includes these note details in the Supported Compliance Tasks by Country/Region table. To find this information, search by Country/Region and Task and the specific Submission Implementation Overview SAP Note. For example, if you search for United Kingdom and the task VAT Return, the Submission Implementation Overview SAP Note 3386362 appears in the Technical Information column.
  • Onboarding to the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition: If you have entitlement through your license then the next step is the Initial Setup of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition.
  • Connecting the Cloud Edition and the Business System: After onboarding, you must setup the Integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with your S/4HANA business system.
    • Communication Setup details, with all the information required for the backend setup, are available at: Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP S/4HANA 
  • Reporting Configuration in the Business System and Cloud Edition: The final step is the specific configuration for your report.  Here you need to complete the following two main configurations: 
    • Configure your process-specific setting and authentication method for your reports per country/region in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition (SAP BTP). Please verify it per your specific report at Process-Specific Setting.
    • Configure each statutory report by following the steps in the individual configuration documentation. You can find the configuration documentation in SAP S/4HANA by navigating to the links in the Reports column in the Reports Enabled for Electronic Submission.

I hope this guide can provide a comprehensive understanding of the configuration steps and where to find all relevant information for the configuration of the communication setup in SAP S/4HANA Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition and SAP S/4HANA Cloud business systems.

Thank you and see you next time.

entry.title: Provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud Connect and Enrolling with Existing Databricks
entry.content:
Hi, community!

Trust me when I say I know how difficult it may be to follow SAP Help Portal instructions, especially when you have to move from different platforms, let alone having to wait for a button to become visible!

Recently, I worked on some documentation for provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Connect and enrolling it with an existing Databricks setup. Since it may seem tricky to perform this task at first, I decided to make a short video to guide you through the process.

Setting up SAP BDC Connect with an existing Databricks environment gives you a dedicated space where the two systems work together seamlessly, enabling bidirectional data sharing. In this setup, SAP BDC Connect assigns resources and puts the right settings in place—so your external systems are fully prepared, integrated with SAP BDC and ready to run advanced data processes without extra hassle. 

Curious how it all comes together? Grab a coffee and follow along with the how-to video below—I’ll walk you through each step of the provisioning process.

 

This video was made in an internal SAP test system.

I hope this walkthrough made the process clearer and saved you some time. Setting up SAP BDC with Databricks doesn’t have to be overwhelming—once you know the steps, it’s actually pretty straightforward. If you run into questions along the way, don’t hesitate to revisit the video or check the SAP Business Data Cloud Connect documentation for extra details. As always, we're here to help you.

If you liked reading this post, feel free to share it with your colleagues. Also, I invite you to follow my profile and leave a comment or a question. Remember to follow the SAP Business Data Cloud tag to get the latest news available.

All the best,

Eduardo

entry.title: Re: Parallel accounting activation in future
entry.content:
Hello @ai_takahashi 

Recommendation

J62 – Asset Accounting (FI-AA): Activate any fixed assets now for initial setup. J62 serves as the core FI-AA foundation and is included as a standard scope item for Public Cloud. Delaying activation typically increases migration and testing efforts. SAP Help Portal-Asset Accounting-Scope Items for Asset Accounting

1GB – Asset Accounting for Group Ledger (IFRS): Activate with J62 if IFRS ledger reporting for assets is needed. 1GB covers IFRS/group ledger FI-AA scope. If not needed now, defer 1GB, but plan your parallel ledger and depreciation areas to prevent rework.

Note on 1GA: 1GA covers the G/L close for the IFRS group ledger; it does not replace FI-AA. Asset-level IFRS valuations are linked to 1GB, not 1GA. SAP Support Portal-3530183 - Assigning Accounting Principles to Ledgers and Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Details on Configuration in General Ledger Accounting and Asset Accounting

If you defer a 1GB post go-live, do it via a change project and (if required) raise a scope item activation request for component XX-S4C-OPR-SRV. SAP Support Portal-3045179 - Request to activate scope item

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Challenges in Modify Batch Details at Sub-Item Level...
entry.content:
Hello @ashoktirumalasetti30 

Thank you for your question

There is no released BAdI to clear or modify delivery batch-split sub-items at save/PGI time in public cloud. However, SAP supports a configuration.

  • You can set up Batch Determination in deliveries so that once the required quantity is covered, the system will not propose additional batches
  • You can also assign the search procedure to the delivery item category and test it from the Manage Outbound Deliveries.
  • If your user created extra splits manually, ensure you re-run batch determination in the item; the system should propose only what is needed you will not have a clear sub-item to pass PGI.

If you are on EWM, ensure you use stock removal strategies and picking rules. This will ensure no batches over-picking instead of trying to clear them programmatically.

Have a look at Definition of a Batch Search Strategy, Batch Determination for Deliveries & Extensibility for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Unlocking AI: Understanding Joule and SAP Business AI from Strategy to Activation
entry.content:
As organizations look to harness the power of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to drive transformation, SAP Business AI stands at the forefront - embedding intelligence directly into business processes to deliver smarter decisions and measurable outcomes.

From finance and supply chain to HR, procurement, and customer experience, SAP Business AI infuses trusted, relevant, and responsible AI across every process - ensuring each insight is contextual, every recommendation actionable, and every outcome aligned with enterprise goals.

Whether leveraging Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, or AI-embedded scenarios across your SAP applications, your path to becoming an intelligent and sustainable enterprise begins with understanding and activating SAP’s Business AI capabilities.

To help you unlock this value faster, we’re launching a new Expert-Guided Implementation (EGI): 

Unlocking AI: Joule and SAP Business AI from Strategy to Activation

This multi-day, expert-led workshop is designed to help you and your team unlock the full potential of Joule and SAP Business AI across your SAP landscape. Guided by SAP experts, you’ll explore how to translate strategy into execution with practical exercises, live demonstrations, and activation guidance.

Workshop Schedule

To accommodate global participants, this session will be offered in two time zones:

  • October 20–22, 2025 | 10:00am–12:00pm EMEA time zone

  • November 3–5, 2025 | 10:00am –12:00pm NY time zone


What You’ll Learn

Through this EGI, participants will gain hands-on experience and actionable knowledge in:

  • SAP Business AI Strategy & Foundation - Understand SAP’s AI vision, architecture, and trusted approach to delivering responsible, embedded intelligence
  • Commercial Model & AI Units - Learn how to navigate Base vs Premium models, the AI Feature Catalog, and use the AI Estimator to plan your adoption journey
  • Joule – AI Built for Business - Explore Joule’s unified architecture, roadmap, and capabilities across Joule for Business, Joule for Developers, and Joule for Consultants
  • S/4HANA AI & ML Capabilities - Experience ISLM in action through AI/ML demo use cases designed to enhance decision-making and process automation
  • SAP BTP AI & ML Capabilities - Discover how BTP AI Foundation, Document AI, AI Services, AI Core, and AI Launchpad can help you extend and scale innovation
  • Joule Activation & Prerequisites - Gain a clear view of activation steps, prerequisites, and how to extend Joule with Document Grounding, Joule Studio, and AI Agents

Why Attend

This workshop goes beyond theory—it’s interactive, practical, and guided by SAP experts. By the end, you’ll have:

  • A clear understanding of SAP’s Business AI strategy and product portfolio
  • The ability to activate Joule and deploy AI scenarios across your landscape
  •  Actionable steps to integrate AI and Generative AI into your business workflows
  • Insights into commercial models and AI unit management for smarter planning

Whether you’re a business leader shaping AI strategy or a technical consultant implementing it, this EGI equips you to bridge the gap between strategy and execution.

How to Register

👉 Register here to secure your spot* today to learn from SAP experts and gain the skills to bring Business AI to life across your enterprise.

 * You may need to register your S-user for access to SAP Learning Hub to access the EGI registration page.  It is a one-time registration, click here.

entry.title: Re: SAP MDG - Material - Class & characteristics
entry.content:
Hello @pankaj0708 

Thank you for your question

You cannot directly attach a custom F4 to a characteristic in the classification system within the public cloud.

SAP supports the creation of Custom Business Object that holds your parent values, then create a custom field for the parent characterisctics that references the CBO. The system will then generate the F4 from it automatically.

Alternatively, you can build a small Custom Fiori app where the parent field dropdown is created from your custom table through a CDS view or CBO service.

Have a look at Custom Business Objects, Custom Fields and Logic & Key User Extensibility links for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to have value help for custom field ba...
entry.content:
Hello @P00019191 

Yes, S/4HANA Public Cloud supports this feature, but only when your value help comes from a Core Data Services (CDS)–based code list, not a static list.

Static code lists (typed values) are visible to all users and cannot be filtered by authorisation, so everyone sees the same list. SAP Support Portal-3612451 - Custom Fields - Frequently Asked Questions - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit – Migrate Directly from SAP System – Increase flexibility by using Spl
entry.content:
Hi all, 

Have you ever wondered how to create multiple entries in a target parameter of the target API using just one source table entry? Have you ever had the requirement to migrate one material to multiple plants although the material is only available in one plant in your source SAP system?  

With SAP S/4HANA 2025, a new feature is available for the S/4HANA Migration Cockpit called "Split Logic", which can be accessed using the Migration Object Modeler (transaction LTMOM). Note that this feature is only available for the migration approach "Migrate Data Directly from SAP System". 

Usually, one entry is created in the target parameter for each assigned source table entry. Using the "Split Logic" feature, you can define a split for the source table to create multiple entries in the target parameter for each source table entry.  

There are two types of split logic - simple split logic and advanced split logic. You can use simple split logic to create a fixed number of entries in the target parameter for each source table entry. Using the advanced split logic, you have a flexible way of defining the number of splits using rules. 

You have then the possibility to define different field mapping information for each of the so-called "splits". 

Some use cases for split logic include: 

  • Creating multiple entries in the target parameter based on one source entry (for example if you want to create a material in multiple plants, whereas previously the material was only available in one plant in the source system) 
  • Handling more complex migration requirements, for example if data in the source system is stored differently than in the target API. 

 We highly recommend reading our recently published SAP Note 3595079 for more information about this topic. 

 Let us know how you might use the split logic and feel free to comment below!  

  All the best for your project!

entry.title: Re: SAP MM03 LAYOUT NOT Available
entry.content:
Hello @jerrysam 

Thank you for your question

Based on your screenshot, your Fiori app layout seems to be customized or corrupt. You can fix it by:

Opening the Display Material app and resetting your personalisation. This can be done in the user settings à Reset Layout

If that does not help, ask your admin to reset user personalisation. After that, ensure you clear your browser cache or refresh the page.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP MM03 LAYOUT NOT Available
entry.content:
Hello @jerrysam 

 Delete Personalisation Data (/UI2/FLP_DEL_PERS): how admins reset Fiori Launchpad/app personalisations for a user. Use this if your MM03 (GUI for HTML) layout is stuck; deleting the user’s personalisation restores the default layout. SAP Help/Delete Personalization Data

With best regardsChuma

entry.title: Re: How to add account assignment columns to PR item tabl...
entry.content:
Hello @Simon__R 

Thank you for your question

Answer to question 1:

There is currently no way to add new columns directly to the item table in the My inbox Purchase Requisition approval task UI. This is because the workflow UI is based on a fixed CDS view that you cannot extend in public cloud.

Answer to question 2:

Yes, you can achieve this through Custom Fields and logic by exposing these fields in the Manage Purchase Requisitions or analytical apps.

Alternatively, you can Build a Custom Task UI that consumes the PR API and joins account assignment data by using CDS Views. Then you can link it to your custom workflow scenario.

 

Consult the following links for more insights.

https://help.sap.com/docs/workflow-capability/workflow-neo/building-custom-task-ui?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/bacc21e14d6c4b0fbf53dca3218abdd5.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/c3dd425f2be1431abc0469a53174786d.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2508.500

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/55a7cb346519450cb9e6d21c1ecd6ec1/20a91308a4304cc297e2f2e36198c616.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2508.500

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Transfer Custom Field from Business Partner to Sales...
entry.content:
HI @Katharinam 

Thank you for your question

Yes, it is possible in public cloud. In-app extensibility will come in handy for that.

Consider these steps:

  • You need to create the custom Field in both Business Partner and Sales Oder business contexts.
  • Then you will have to implement the BAdI in the Custom Fields and Logic app.
  • In your implementation, read the Business Partner’s custom field value and assign it to the Sales Order’s custom field when the order is created.

Consult the following links for more insights.

In-App Extension /Key User Extension

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/ee9ee0ca4c3942068ea584d2f929b5b1/14746cbb39a9474183b6e9ac25ee90d2.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/85043858ea0f9244e10000000a4450e5.html?locale=en-US

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Automatically Align Document, Pricing, and Billing Da...
entry.content:
Hello @Katharinam 

Please note that the Document Date, Pricing Date and Billing Date are not automatically synchronised. This is because they are all standard fields at the sales order header level.

Similar to your other question, the in-app extensibility will also do this. The steps below are necessary:

  1. Go to Custom Fields and Logic --> Sales Document.
  2. Then you need to implement the Define Field Value for Sales Document BAdI.
  3. In your logic, copy the Document Date value to the pricing date and billing date whenever the order is created or changed.

Optionally, you can make the pricing and billing date fields read-only via Adapt UI, this will ensure they always follow your document date.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Certification: One-Stop-Shop for Enteprise Architects and Transformation Consultants
